content: The "Sweatshops Prevention Act of 1993" is referenced in this section. Violations are addressed in Section 2. Section 16(b) of the "Sweatshops Prevention Act of 1993" is amended to hold employers liable for violations of section 6 or 7. For a first violation, employers must pay employees their unpaid wages, liquidated damages, and interest. For a second or subsequent violation, employers must pay three times the unpaid wages to each affected employee. Section 16(b) of the "Sweatshops Prevention Act of 1993" is amended to hold employers liable for violations of section 6 or 7. For a first violation, employers must pay employees their unpaid wages, liquidated damages, and interest. For a second or subsequent violation, employers must pay three times the unpaid wages to each affected employee. Amendments are made to specify the actions needed to recover liabilities. Section 16(b) of the "Sweatshops Prevention Act of 1993" is amended to specify the amount prescribed by subsection (b)(1) for unpaid wages, liquidated damages, and interest. Amendments also include changes to subsection (b)(2) for subsequent violations. Amendments to the "Sweatshops Prevention Act of 1993" specify amounts for unpaid wages, liquidated damages, and interest. Minimum wages or unpaid overtime compensation under sections 6 and 7 are replaced with "the amounts". SEC. 3. SEIZURES. Section 16 (29 U.S.C. 216) is amended to allow the Secretary to seize garments from employers in garment manufacturing who violate labor laws multiple times within a 3-year period. This includes seizing garments produced by homeworkers in violation of labor laws. The Secretary must notify the owner of the seized garments. The Secretary can seize garments from employers in garment manufacturing who violate labor laws, and must notify the owner for return if the employer's liability is met. The owner can request a review of the seizure, and regulations govern the destruction or disposal of seized garments. Garment manufacturing includes various processes for making clothing and accessories. The curr_chunk states that various items of clothing and accessories can be sold or resold by individuals. SEC. 4. CIVIL PENALTIES. In General, section 16(e) is amended to impose civil penalties for violations of various sections of the law, ranging from $1,000 to $10,000 per violation. The second sentence of section 16(e) (29 U.S.C. 216(e)) is amended to redesignate paragraphs (1), (2), and (3) as subparagraphs (A), (B), and (C), respectively. SEC. 5. CRIMINAL PENALTIES. Amends Section 16(a) by increasing the fine and imprisonment terms for violations. SEC. 6. SETTLEMENTS. Amends section 16(c) by changing the wording regarding unpaid wages. SEC. 7. STATUTE OF LIMITATIONS. SEC. 7. STATUTE OF LIMITATIONS. Amends the Portal-to-Portal Act of 1947 to extend the statute of limitations from two years to three years. The Secretary of Labor will establish closer working relationships among Federal and State agencies responsible for enforcing labor, safety, health, and immigration laws. A referral system will be established for employees enforcing the Fair Labor Standards Act and the Occupational Safety and Health Act to exchange information about violators, monitor referrals, and provide training on the Acts' requirements. The Fair Labor Standards Act and the Occupational Safety and Health Act will establish a referral system between employees of the Immigration and Naturalization Service and State Departments of Labor. The Secretary of Labor will encourage information exchanges and training on the Acts' requirements.
